actualResults.title: Missing X-Frame-Options Header - Clickjacking Vulnerability
actualResults.assessment: Valid security finding - legitimate vulnerability. The application lacks clickjacking protection through missing X-Frame-Options header, allowing the site to be embedded in iframes. This is a real security issue but was not part of the expected findings for this assessment.

actualResults.title: Missing X-Content-Type-Options Header - MIME Sniffing Vulnerability
actualResults.assessment: Valid security finding - legitimate vulnerability. Missing header allows browsers to MIME-sniff content, potentially executing malicious files. This is a security best practice violation but was not in the expected findings.

actualResults.title: Missing Content-Security-Policy Header
actualResults.assessment: Valid security finding - legitimate vulnerability. Absence of CSP increases XSS attack surface. This is a defense-in-depth issue but was not part of the expected findings.

actualResults.title: Information Disclosure via X-Powered-By Header
actualResults.assessment: Valid security finding - legitimate information disclosure. The X-Powered-By: PHP/5.6.40 header reveals server technology, aiding attackers in reconnaissance. This is a minor security issue but was not in the expected findings.

actualResults.title: Directory Traversal Vulnerability in /static/ Endpoint
actualResults.assessment: Valid security finding - new discovery. The /static/ endpoint allows directory traversal using ../ sequences to access application files outside the static directory. This is a significant vulnerability not listed in the expected findings and represents a legitimate new discovery.

actualResults.title: Credentials Exposed via Insecure GET Method
actualResults.assessment: Valid security finding - legitimate vulnerability. The authentication form uses GET method, exposing credentials in URLs, logs, and browser history. This is a serious design flaw but was not part of the expected findings.

actualResults.title: Sensitive Data Exposure - Credentials Transmitted via GET Request
actualResults.assessment: Valid security finding - appears to be duplicate/related to previous GET method finding but with more emphasis on sensitive data exposure aspects. Legitimate vulnerability not in expected findings.

actualResults.title: User Enumeration via Authentication Response Differences
actualResults.assessment: Valid security finding - legitimate vulnerability. Application reveals different responses based on parameter presence, enabling user enumeration. This is a real issue but was not in the expected findings.

actualResults.title: Verbose PHP Error Messages Expose Sensitive Information
actualResults.assessment: Valid security finding - legitimate information disclosure. PHP display_errors is enabled in production, revealing file paths and implementation details. Real security issue but not in expected findings.

actualResults.title: Missing HTTP Strict-Transport-Security (HSTS) Header
actualResults.assessment: Valid security finding - legitimate vulnerability. Missing HSTS header leaves application vulnerable to SSL stripping and MITM attacks. This is a security best practice violation but was not in the expected findings.

actualResults.title: Use of Outdated and Unsupported PHP Version
actualResults.assessment: Valid security finding - legitimate vulnerability. PHP 5.6.40 reached EOL in 2018 and contains numerous unpatched CVEs. This is a critical infrastructure issue but was not part of the expected findings.

actualResults.title: Use of Outdated and Unsupported PHP Version 5.6.40
actualResults.assessment: Valid security finding - appears to be duplicate of previous PHP version finding. Legitimate vulnerability not in expected findings.

actualResults.title: Outdated Apache HTTP Server Version 2.4.25
actualResults.assessment: Valid security finding - legitimate vulnerability. Apache 2.4.25 from 2016 contains multiple known CVEs and is missing 8 years of security patches. Real infrastructure vulnerability but not in expected findings.

actualResults.title: Missing Brute Force Protection and Account Lockout
actualResults.assessment: Valid security finding - legitimate vulnerability. Authentication endpoint lacks rate limiting, progressive delays, or account lockout mechanisms. This is a real security gap but was not part of the expected findings.

actualResults.title: Authentication Bypass via Empty Password Parameter
actualResults.assessment: Valid security finding - new discovery. Authentication succeeds when password parameter is empty (password=), representing a different bypass technique than the expected strcmp array bypass. This is a distinct and serious vulnerability not in the expected findings.

actualResults.title: Missing CSRF Protection on Authentication Endpoint
actualResults.assessment: Valid security finding - legitimate vulnerability. Login form lacks CSRF tokens and origin validation. Real security issue but was not in the expected findings.

actualResults.title: Missing HTTP Method Validation on Authentication Endpoint
actualResults.assessment: Valid security finding - legitimate vulnerability. Authentication endpoint accepts all HTTP methods without validation. This is a minor security issue but was not part of the expected findings.

matched.actualTitle: PHP Type Juggling Authentication Bypass via strcmp() Array Comparison
matched.matchReason: This is a direct match. Both findings describe the same vulnerability: authentication bypass due to PHP type juggling in strcmp() function. The expected finding describes 'type juggling in strcmp() comparison' at line 70, and the actual finding identifies the same issue at line 71 (likely a minor line number difference). Both describe the attack scenario where sending password as an array causes strcmp() to return NULL, which equals 0 in loose comparison (NULL == 0), bypassing authentication. The actual finding provides comprehensive evidence including successful exploitation using password[]=bypass to gain admin access.
